newsitem.title: USA: Yankee issuers stir calm US corporate primary mart.
newsitem.headline: Yankee issuers stir calm US corporate primary mart.

text.p: A number of yankee debt offerings have stirred up activity in a relatively quiet corporate bond primary market as most domestic players remain on the sidelines, dealers said.
"There's still no official calendar but some issuers are stepping in on any dips in Treasury yields to price debt," one syndicate source said.

Wednesday's yankee debt offerings were well received, dealers said. European Investment Bank's 10-year global bonds were seen trading firmly, where initially priced, at a spread of 17 basis points over Treasuries.
"EAB's issue came at a spread of 17 basis points and has held firm at that level," said one syndicate source.
So far on Thursday, Anixter International Inc priced $100 million seven-year notes to yield 135 basis points over Treasuries via Merrill Lynch & Co, dealers said.
Comerica Inc is expected to price $150 million in A2/A rated 30-year subordinated debt via CS First Boston. Price talk on the issue is seen in the 85-87 basis points area, dealers said.
Among other names rumored to come to market are Wells Fargo and Co and NationsBank, sources added.
In the private placement sector, United USN Inc is expected to set $155 million in eight-year 144A senior notes.
Also, First Nationwide Holdings is expected to price $525 million in seven-year senior subordinated 144A notes via Smith Barney.
In other yankee offerings, Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd priced $500 million in 10-year yankee subordinated notes to yield a spread of 64 basis points via Merrill Lynch & Co.
"ANZ's 10-year deal was very successful," said one syndicate source. "It was upped in size to $500 million from an initial size of $400 million to meet investor demand."
Meanwhile, Tennessee Valley Authority priced DM 1.5 billion 10-year global bonds to yield a spread of 17 basis points.
TVA and EIB saved millions of dollars by avoiding the currency swap market on their huge global bond issues by enacting a direct, back-to-back swap agreement, dealers said.
TVA gave the mark proceeds of its deal to EIB in return for the bank's dollar proceeds. The two will also exchange interest payments on the bonds, dealers added.
